subject: RE: [junit] splitting this list
msgSnippet: ... I can t get my brain around that statement.  How can asking a question (which must include a 2nd party) be helping yourself (which cannot include a 2nd
messageBody:
Jason Rogers wrote:
> But, you fail to consider that for some people (especially in
> different
> cultures) the first way to help yourself may be to ask a
> question.

I can't get my brain around that statement. How
can "asking a question" (which must include a 2nd
party) be "helping yourself" (which cannot include a
2nd party)?

> You have also failed to consider that in some
> countries Google is not necessarily a buzz-word, so the
> question may not be directed there.

That's true - I didn't really consider that. Maybe
I'm being close-minded, but it's hard to fathom that
a person can find a website to sign up for an email
list, but then be unable to do a web search. Heck,
the JUnit web page itself has two different web search
fields on it - one for the web in general, and one
to search for content of prior messages. If this
list was about learning basic computing skills, I
might believe what you wrote. But everyone here is
in the software development field. How do you get
to be a practicing software development professional
(or student) in the 21st century without knowing how
to do a web search? (That question isn't totally
rhetorical. If there really is a way, I'd love to
hear about it.)


Simon Chappell wrote:
> That does take a few minutes, but it's the nicest way to deal
> with that sort of person that I've seen. This list is very
> friendly and helpful and populated by some fine people, so
> the last thing we want to do is to seem judgemental or rude.

Whoa! I definitely didn't mean to imply that I
recommend being rude or judgmental to anyone. I
would hope that a separate beginner's list would
continue to be just as polite and helpful as this
list is today.


J.B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Todd, I appreciate your concern and have raised that myself,
> in the past.

Yes, I know we've discussed it here.

> I would find it difficult to stay on this list
> myself, if it weren't so low traffic. Also take into
> consideration the number of posts we already reject, because
> the questions are too basic.

Wow, I did not realize that there are posts getting
actively rejected! If this is a moderated list,
it seems like the moderators could easily reply
to the "whats junit" type of questions with a link
to the FAQ and never pass those on to the rest of
the group.

> If we don't encourage the
> general public to post their questions, then who will we have
> to discuss interesting topics with in a few years?

Perhaps I'm self-centered, because I expect others
to take the same general approach to learning a new
technology that I do, which is: read what I can
about it until I get stuck, then read more from a
different author, and if I'm still stuck, then ask
for help. I believe that the people who do NOT take
that approach aren't likely to be here to discuss
the interesting topics in a few years. I believe
that the people who ask the obvious FAQs get just
enough info to complete their homework assignment
or placate their boss or whatever, and then disappear
and don't participate in further discussions. But
that's just a hunch. Maybe I should do a random
survey of "not-smart" questions from 2 years ago to
see if those people are the ones now actively con-
tributing to the discussion here.


Mike wrote:
> As a newbie user/lurker myself I don't recall reading the
> FAQ, but have made a note to look it up now...

Just today I unsubscribed and then resubscribed,
to confirm that the FAQ is automatically emailed
to new members. I wonder if the auto mailer
doesn't work for everyone.


Todd.
